original_theorem:
Suppose that  $f$ is infinitely differentiable on an interval $I$ and
\begin{equation}\label{eq:4.5.18}
\lim_{n\to\infty}\frac{r^n}{ n!}\|f^{(n)}\|_I=0.
\end{equation}
Then$,$ if $x_0\in I^0,$ the Taylor series
$$
\sum^\infty_{n=0}\frac{f^{(n)}(x_0)}{ n!} (x-x_0)^n
$$
 converges uniformly to $f$ on
$$
I_r=I\cap [x_0-r,x_0+r].
$$
theorem_translation:
```lean4
theorem taylor_series_uniform_convergence_on_ir {f : ‚Ñù ‚Üí ‚Ñù} {I : Set ‚Ñù} {x‚ÇÄ r : ‚Ñù}
    (hI_open : IsOpen I) (hf_diff_inf : ContDiffOn ‚Ñù ‚ä§ f I)
    (hl_lim : Tendsto (fun n : ‚Ñï => r^n / (n! : ‚Ñù) * (‚®Ü (s : I), ‚Äñ(deriv^[n] f) s‚Äñ)) atTop (ùìù 0))
    (hx‚ÇÄ_mem_I_interior : x‚ÇÄ ‚àà interior I) :
    let Ir := I ‚à© Set.Icc (x‚ÇÄ - r) (x‚ÇÄ + r)
    TendstoUniformlyOn (fun n x => ‚àë k in Finset.range (n + 1), (deriv^[k] f) x‚ÇÄ / (k! : ‚Ñù) * (x - x‚ÇÄ)^k) f atTop Ir := by sorry
```

proof_steps.natural_language:
We assume:
‚Ä¢ $f$ is infinitely differentiable on an interval $I$ [tc_1].
‚Ä¢ $x_0$ is a point in the interior of $I$ [tc_3].
‚Ä¢ The n-th Taylor polynomial of $f$ centered at $x_0$ is $T_n(x; x_0) = \sum^n_{k=0}\frac{f^{(k)}(x_0)}{ k!} (x-x_0)^k$ [def_1a].
‚Ä¢ The interval $I_r$ is defined as $I_r = I \cap [x_0-r, x_0+r]$ [def_1b].
Therefore, we conclude:
‚Ä¢ For any $n \ge 0$, the supremum norm of the remainder satisfies $\|f-T_n(x;x_0)\|_{I_r} \le \frac{r^{n+1}}{(n+1)!}\|f^{(n+1)}\|_I$ [l1].
proof_steps.lean_tactics:

  have h_remainder_bound : ‚àÄ n : ‚Ñï, ‚àÄ x : Ir, ‚Äñf x - (‚àë k in Finset.range (n + 1), (deriv^[k] f) x‚ÇÄ / (k! : ‚Ñù) * (x - x‚ÇÄ)^k)‚Äñ ‚â§ (r^(n+1) / ((n+1)! : ‚Ñù)) * (‚®Ü (s : I), ‚Äñ(deriv^[n+1] f) s‚Äñ) := by
    intro n x
    apply taylor_series_remainder_bound_at_point f hf_diff_inf hx‚ÇÄ_mem_I_interior r x‚ÇÄ (mem_of_subset_of_mem (Set.inter_subset_right _ _) x.property)
